installedMtdApps.description: A comma-delimited list of supported Android Mobile Threat Defense (MTD) applications installed on the device

installedMtdAppsRisk.description: The risk associated with the device based on the MTD applications installed

AspRiskSummary.description:
An object containing the Android vulnerability details
The Secure Endpoint Agent for Android is no longer supported and all existing Android devices have been unenrolled from their respective accounts

eventDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the device unenrollment status last changed

id.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the Move Devices request

status.description:
Indicates the status of the request
  • `Processing`: the request is in progress
  • `Completed`: the request is complete and all devices are now associated with the target policy group
  • `Failed`: the request failed
  • `Timeout`: the request exceeded the maximum processing time, and it has timed out

name.description:
The user-defined name of the Freeze message shown on the device when the device is frozen
Between 1 and 255 characters

content.description:
The user-defined, HTML coded Freeze message
Between 1 and 4000 characters

The system validates message content and automatically removes any HTML tags or attributes that may expose Absolute servers or agents to injection attacks, such as cross site scripting (XSS).

deviceUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the device

esn.description: The system-defined unique identifier (Absolute Identifier) assigned to the Secure Endpoint Agent installed on the device

compliant.description:
The compliance status of the device
  • `true`: The device is compliant
  • `false`: The device is not compliant
  • `unknown`: The status of the device is not available

numberOfDaysOffline.description: The number of days since the device last called in to the Absolute Monitoring Center

reasons.description: An array of objects, each object represents a reason why the device is not compliant

deviceName.description: The name assigned to the device

lastConnectedUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the device last connected to the Absolute Monitoring Center

dnsHostName.description: The host name used to identify the device (the default Microsoft networking computer name) that matches the local IP

macAddress.description: The media access control (MAC) address of the network adapter that matches the local IP

networkAdapters.description: An array of objects, each object represents one of the device's network adapters

lastCompliantUpdatedUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the device's compliance status was last updated in the database

statusDetails.description: The details of the status

policyGroupUids.description: The system-defined unique identifiers of the policy groups included in the request

items.description: The system-defined unique identifiers of the policy groups included in the request

encryptionProductName.description: The name of the encryption product

encryptionVersion.description: The version of the encryption product

encryptionStatusDescription.description: The description of the encryption status

encryptionKeySize.description: The size of the encryption key

hardwareEncryption.description: Indicates whether hardware encryption is used

lastEncryptionDataReceivedUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) when encryption data was last received

allDrivesEncrypted.description: Indicates whether all drives are encrypted

id.description:
The identifier of the processor system
Chromebook devices return a value of `1`

name.description: The label by which the CPU is known

architecture.description:
The processor architecture used by the platform
Mapped values for Windows devices
  • `0`: x86
  • `1`: MIPS
  • `2`: Alpha
  • `3`: PowerPC
  • `5`: ARM
  • `6`: Itanium-based systems
  • `9`: x64

busSpeed.description: The rate (in megahertz) at which the processor bus of the device can transmit data

dataWidth.description:
The width of the data bus
  • `32`: 32-bit processor
  • `64`: 64-bit processor

gpuModel.description: The model of the built-in graphics processing unit (GPU)

gpuSpeed.description: The speed of the built-in graphics processing unit (GPU)

instructionSet.description:
The width of the data bus
  • `32`: 32-bit processor
  • `64`: 64-bit processor

logicalCores.description: The number of logical processors for the current instance of the processor

physicalCores.description: The number of physical cores for the current instance of the processor

processorSpeed.description: The current speed (in megahertz) of the processor

l2CacheSpeed.description: The clock speed (in hertz) of the Level 2 processor cache

l2CacheSize.description: The size (in bytes) of the Level 2 processor cache

l3CacheSpeed.description: The clock speed (in hertz) of the Level 3 processor cache

l3CacheSize.description: The size (in bytes) of the Level 3 processor cache

Cpu.description: An object containing information about the device's CPU

deviceUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the device that was not successfully reported missing or found

reason.description: The reason that the device was not successfully reported missing or found

DeviceMissingFailDetail.description: An array of objects, each object represents an error that occurred while reporting devices missing or found

deviceUids.description: The system-defined unique identifiers of the devices included in the request

items.description: The system-defined unique identifiers of the devices included in the request

excludeMissingDevices.description:
Indicates whether devices that have been reported Missing should be excluded from the request
  • `false` (default): devices reported Missing are included in the request
  • `true`: devices reported Missing are excluded from the request

messageName.description: The user-defined name of the Freeze message

htmlClear.description:
The user-defined, HTML coded Freeze message
The same as `configuration.freezeMessage` except it contains the HTML tags

passcodeClear.description: The 4 to 8 digit numerical unfreeze code that can be used to immediately unfreeze a frozen device

passcodeOption.description:
The method used to generate the unfreeze code
  • `UserDefined`: a user-defined unfreeze code was generated and is the same for all devices
  • `RandomForAll`: an unfreeze code was randomly generated and is the same for all devices
  • `RandomForEach`: a unique unfreeze code was randomly generated for each device

freezeMessage.description:
The user-defined Freeze message without the HTML tags
The same as `configuration.htmlClear` except it does not contain the HTML tags

freezeId.description:
The user-friendly identifier of the Freeze request that is displayed in event history in the Secure Endpoint Console
The same as `eventHistoryId`

action.description:
The type of action being performed on the device
Always `DFZ`

type.description:
The type of Freeze
  • `OnDemand`: Freezes the device on the next connection with the Absolute Monitoring Center, typically within 15 minutes
  • `Scheduled`: Freezes a device on its next connection with the Absolute Monitoring Center on or after a specified date and time

passcodeLength.description: The length of the unfreeze code when the unfreeze code is randomly generated

passcodeSalt.description: The salt used for hashing the unfreeze code before the unfreeze code is sent to the device

passcodeHashed.description: The hashed value of the unfreeze code

disableRemoteLogin.description:
Indicates whether remote login is disabled on the device
  • `true`: remote login is disabled
  • `false`: remote login is enabled on the device

disableFileSharing.description:
Indicates whether file sharing is disabled on the device
  • `true`: file sharing is disabled
  • `false`: file sharing is enabled on the device

forceReboot.description:
Previously, Windows devices required a reboot in order to completely Freeze the device
This setting is no longer used

preLoginEnabled.description:
Indicates whether prelogin is enabled on the device
  • `true`: prelogin is enabled
  • `false`: prelogin is disabled on the device

serviceControlList.description: The list of service controls that the server sends to the device

issuedDateTimeUTC.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the Freeze request was created

conditions.description:
An array of objects, each object represents the conditions of the Freeze request
When `configuration.type` is `OnDemand`, this is an empty array

DfzConfiguration.description: An object containing information about the Freeze request

additionalProperties.description:
The parameter name and value

To specify device specific information in a parameter, you can use a variable. To view the list of supported variables, use the GET /actions/playbook/datasources endpoint.

For more information about configuring each playbook's parameters and using variables, see Running playbooks in the console help.

params.description: An array of objects, where each object represents a parameter used to configure the playbook action

PlaybookIsoCommandModel.description: An array of objects, where each object represents the playbook action you want to include in the request. You can include up to 20 actions.

encryptionProductName.description:
The name of the full-disk encryption product detected on the device
See Detected full-disk encryption products in the online help for details about the full-disk encryption products and self-encrypting products that can be detected

encryptionVersion.description: The version number of the full-disk encryption program detected on the device

encryptionAlgorithm.description:
The detected algorithm used by the full-disk encryption program, if available
Most products use Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)

encryptionStatusDescription.description: The summarized encryption status of the device

encryptionKeySize.description:
The number of bits in a key used by the detected algorithm
For products that use an AES algorithm, the key size is typically 128 or 256 bits

hardwareEncryption.description:
If `true`, an Opal compliant self-encrypting drive (SED) is detected on the device
If `false`, the encryption product is software based

lastEncryptionDataReceivedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and (ISO 8601) time when the agent last detected a change in the device's encryption information

encryptionStatus.description:
The summarized encryption status of the device
  • `ENCR`: a full-disk encryption product is installed on the device and device's system drive is encrypted
  • `INST`: a full-disk encryption product is installed on the device but the device's system drive is not encrypted
  • `UNKN`: a full-disk encryption product is not detected on the device
  • `SUSP` (Windows only): BitLocker Drive Encryption is suspended
  • `INPR` (Windows only): the system drive is in the process of being encrypted by BitLocker Drive Encryption
  • `DECRINPR` (Windows only): the system drive is in the process of being decrypted by BitLocker Drive Encryption

allDrivesEncrypted.description:
Indicates whether all drives have been encrypted
USB drives and network drives are ignored
  • `0`: no drives are encrypted
  • `1`: all drives are encrypted with locked drives
  • `2`: all drives are encrypted with no locked drives
  • `3`: some drives are encrypted
  • `4`: the encryption status of all drives is unknown

EncryptionDataChanged.description: An object containing information about the full-disk encryption product detected on the device

deviceUids.description: List of device UIDs to assign licenses to

items.description: List of device UIDs to assign licenses to

baseLicenses.description: List of base licenses to assign

items.description: List of base licenses to assign

addonLicenses.description: List of addon licenses to assign

items.description: List of addon licenses to assign

requestType.description: Type of request: ADD, REPLACE, or REMOVE

id.description: The identifier of the cellular modem

description.description: The description of the cellular modem

enabled.description: If `true`, the cellular modem is enabled

imei.description: The International Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI), which is used to identify GSM, UMTS, and LTE mobile phones

imsi.description: The Internet Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), which is used to identify the user or subscriber, of a cellular network

simSerialNumber.description: The serial number of the subscriber identity module (SIM) card

currentNetworkName.description: The name of the network which the device currently belongs to

currentNetworkNumericCode.description: The numeric code of the network which the device currently belongs to

homeNetworkName.description: The name of the home network which the device belongs to

homeNetworkNumericCode.description: The numeric code of the home network which the device belongs to

phoneNumber.description: The phone number of the cellular modem

CellularModem.description: An array of objects, each object represents one of the device's cellular modems

deviceUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the device

lastUpdatedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the data point scan results were last updated

result.description: An array of objects, each object represents a data point collected for the device

totalDevices.description: The total number of devices included in the request

pending.description: The number of devices in the request with a status of Pending

processing.description: The number of devices in the request with a status of Processing

completed.description: The number of devices in the request that have a status of Succeeded

canceled.description: The number of devices in the request that have a status of Canceled

failed.description: The number of devices in the request that have a status of Failed

actionId.description: The system-defined action identifier for the request

requestUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the Device Action request

requestStatus.description:
The status of the request
  • `Init`: all devices in the request have an action status of Pending
  • `Canceled`: the request was canceled by the requester while pending approval
  • `Completed`: all the devices in the request have an action status of Completed, Succeeded, Failed, or Canceled
  • `InProgress`: at least one device in the request has an action status of Processing
  • `Failed`: the request failed, the request was declined, or the request was auto declined
  • `Scheduled`: the request is scheduled to take place in the future and all requests have an action status of Pending or Ready
    Applies to Send Message requests only
  • `PendingApproval`: the request is waiting to be approved
    Applies to dual approval requests only

createdDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) that the request was created

updatedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) that the request was last updated

requester.description: The username of the entity that created the request

requestTitle.description: The user-defined title of the request

notificationEmails.description: The notification emails for the request

items.description: The notification emails for the request

scheduledDateTimeUtc.description: The scheduled date and time (ISO 8601) for the request

scriptName.description: The name of the Reach script

scriptUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the Reach script

CreateDeviceGroupTreeRequest_NodeRelatio.description: An object containing information about the parent of the device group or folder

fileName.description: The file name of the Reach script

OsScript.description: Information about the Reach script, including the default Advanced Configuration Options values used to execute the script on devices when they are not specified in the request

status.description:
Whether the data point was successfully collected from the device
  • `success`: the data point was successfully collected from the device
  • `error`: the data point was not successfully collected from the device
  • `warning`: the data point was successfully collected form the device but it exceeded a predefined threshold

statusCode.description:
The numeric code associated with the `lastError`
  • `0`: No error occurred.
  • `1`: A failure occurred evaluating the data item logic, the exact error should be troubleshooted by looking at the included trace.
  • `2`: Rule evaluation for this item exceeded the configured timeout value and was terminated.
  • `4`: Rule evaluation exceeded the configured CPU threshold.
  • `8`: Rule evaluation exceeded the configured Memory threshold.
  • `16`: Rule evaluation resulted in output that exceeded the maximum data size for an individual item.

lastError.description: An object representing the last error that occurred while collecting the data point from the device

errorCount.description: The number of errors that occurred while attempting to collect the data point for this device

traceMessages.description: An array of strings, each string represents a trace message that occurred while evaluating the data point on the device

items.description: An array of strings, each string represents a trace message that occurred while evaluating the data point on the device

value.description: The value collected from the device for the data point

CDCDatapointFieldDetail.description: An object containing details about the scan results for the data point

cdfUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the Device Field

cdfFieldName.description: The name of the Device Field

type.description: The data type of the Device Field

categoryCode.description:
The type of Device Field
  • `PREDEFINED`: predefined by Absolute (Fixed Device Field)
  • `ESNCOLUMN`: predefined by Absolute (Fixed Device Field)
  • `UDF`: created and defined by a user (Custom Device Field)
  • `RDF`: deprecated
  • `WEBUSAGE`: deprecated

dropdowns.description:
An array of objects, each object represents one dropdown element
Returns `NULL` if the Device Field does not contain dropdown elements

id.description: The identifier of the printer

name.description: The name of the printer

driver.description: The name of the printer driver

server.description: The name of the server that controls the printer

share.description: The name of the share for the printer

port.description:
The port used to transmit data to the printer
If a printer is connected to more than one port, ports show in a comma-delimited list

Printer.description: An array of objects, each object represents one of the device's printers

option.description:
The method used to generate the unfreeze code
  • `UserDefined`: a user-defined unfreeze code is generated and is the same for all devices
    Set the unfreeze code in `passcodeDefinition.passcode`
  • `RandomForAll`: an unfreeze code is randomly generated and is the same for all devices
    Set the length of the unfreeze code in `passcodeDefinition.length`
  • `RandomForEach`: a unique unfreeze code is randomly generated for each device
    Set the length of the unfreeze code in `passcodeDefinition.length`

passcode.description:
The user-defined 4 to 8 digit numeric unfreeze code that can be used to immediately unfreeze a frozen device
Use when `passcodeDefinition.option` is `UserDefined`

length.description:
The length of the unfreeze code when the unfreeze code is randomly generated
Use when `passcodeDefinition.option` is `RandomForEach` or `RandomForAll`
Must be between 4 and 8
Default: `8`

PasscodeDefinition.description: An object containing information about the unfreeze code that can be used to immediately unfreeze a frozen device

itemId.description: The unique identifier of the scanned item

userName.description: The username of the user on the device

deviceSerialNo.description: The serial number of the device

deviceModelNo.description: The model number of the device

deviceUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the device

fileNameNoPath.description: The name of the file without the path

contentType.description: The content type of the file

matches.description: The number of matches found in the file

matchedTokens.description: The tokens that matched in the file

tokenOffsets.description: The offsets of the matched tokens

tokenLengths.description: The lengths of the matched tokens

algorithmMatchedMetadata.description: The metadata of the algorithm match

mergedViolations.description: The merged violations found in the file

algorithmMatchIndex.description: The index of the algorithm match

mqFileDateTime.description: The date and time of the file in MQ format

fileMatchStatus.description: The match status of the file

scanGuidSequence.description: The sequence number of the scan GUID

fileContentHash.description: The hash of the file content

quotaDelimited.description: Indicates whether the quota is delimited

policyGroupName.description: The name of the policy group

excludeFromReport.description: Indicates whether to exclude from the report

createdDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the file was created

lastAccessedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the file was last accessed

lastedModifiedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the file was last modified

scanDateUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the scan was performed

dlStatusEnabled.description: Indicates whether the DLP policy is enabled

EDDScanResults.description: The results of an Endpoint Data Discovery scan

targetPolicyGroupUid.description: The system-defined unique identifier of the target policy group

deviceUids.description: An array of objects, where each object (`deviceUid`) represents a device to be moved to the target policy group

items.description: An array of objects, where each object (`deviceUid`) represents a device to be moved to the target policy group

isEnabled.description:
Indicates whether the data point should be enabled or disabled for the Custom Data policy
  • `true`: enable the data point in the Custom Data policy
  • `false`: disable the data point in the Custom Data policy

displayName.description:
The display name for the data point
Must be unique
The validation for matching `displayName` is case insensitive, BatteryHealth and batteryHealth are considered the same
If a display name is not assigned when the data point configuration is added, `fieldName` is used

applicationName.description: The name of the application in the Application Resilience policy

trigger.description: The reason the Application Resilience policy was run on the device

version.description: The version of the application that is installed on the device

lastUpdatedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the results of the status check were last updated in the Absolute Monitoring Center

executionCompletedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the status of the application was checked on the device

status.description:
The status of the Application Resilience policy
  • `Enabled`: the Application Resilience policy is enabled on the device
  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

statusDetails.description:
Detailed information on why the Secure Endpoint Agent is unable to repair or reinstall the application when it's not functioning correctly or is missing
See Understanding status details for a persisted application in the Online help for more information on interpreting this error

repairCount.description: The total number of repairs that succeeded on the device over the last 30 days

reinstallCount.description: The total number of reinstallations that succeeded on the device over the last 30 days

failedCount.description: The total number of repairs and reinstallations that failed on the device over the last 30 days

persistentEventCount.description: The total number of repairs and reinstallations attempted on the device over the last 30 days

lastKnownHealthyStatusDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the Secure Endpoint Agent last detected the application changed from a non-compliant (unhealthy) status to a compliant (healthy) status

lastKnownCorruptStatusDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the Secure Endpoint Agent last detected the application changed from a compliant (healthy) status to a non-compliant (unhealthy) status

lastEventCountUpdatedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the Application Resilience event counts were last updated in the Absolute Monitoring Center

status.description:
The status of the Application Resilience policy
  • `Enabled`: the Application Resilience policy is enabled on the device
  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

status.description:
The status of the Application Resilience policy
  • `Enabled`: the Application Resilience policy is enabled on the device
  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

status.description:

  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

status.description:

rnrSmartEye.description: An object containing information about the Application Resilience policy for SmartEye

applicationName.description: The name of the application in the Application Resilience policy

trigger.description: The reason the Application Resilience policy was run on the device

version.description: The version of the application that is installed on the device

executionCompletedDateTimeUtc.description: The date and time (ISO 8601) the status of the application was checked on the device

status.description:
The status of the Application Resilience policy
  • `Enabled`: the Application Resilience policy is enabled on the device
  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

statusDetails.description:

persistentEventCount.description: The total number of repairs and reinstallations attempted on the device over the last 30 days

status.description:
The status of the Application Resilience policy
  • `Enabled`: the Application Resilience policy is enabled on the device
  • `Disabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoCurrentData`: the device has a status of Compliant, no repairs were attempted
  • `NotCompliant`: the device has a status of Not Compliant

repairStatus.description:
The status of any attempted repairs
  • `RepairDisabled`: the Report only option is enabled in the Application Resilience policy
  • `NoRepairs`: the device has a status of Compliant so no repairs were attempted
  • `Success`: all attempted repairs were successful and the device has a status of Compliant
  • `Failure`: the attempted repairs were not successful and the device has a status of Not Compliant
  • `PendingReboot`: a repair was attempted but the device needs to restart to finish the process and the device has a status on Not Compliant

info.title: Absolute API
info.description:
You can use the Absolute Application Program Interface (API) to directly access Absolute functionality and data without using the Secure Endpoint Console. Any business functionality invoked by the API is equivalent to the functionality available through the Secure Endpoint Console. Absolute uses RESTful APIs. # Introduction ## Accessing the API

API access

The URL you use to access the Absolute API depends on which URL you use to access the Secure Endpoint Console. The following table lists each login URL and the corresponding API access URL:

Login URL API access URL
https://cc.absolute.com https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate
https://cc.us.absolute.com https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate
https://cc.eu2.absolute.com https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate
https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate

Prerequisites

There are two prerequisites for the Absolute API:

  • The developer must have a user created in the Secure Endpoint Console that is assigned an Absolute user role. The role can be a default user role, or a custom user role defined by your organization.
  • The user must have at least one API token associated with it in the Secure Endpoint Console. See Create your API token for more information on creating an API token.

Depending on the permissions associated with your API token and the Absolute product licenses associated with your account, some endpoints may not be available to you.

 ## Requests

API requests contain three types of parameters: path, query, and request body schema parameters.

Path parameters

Path parameters are included in the endpoint URI and are surrounded with curly braces ({}). If the endpoint contains a path parameter, the path parameter is described for the endpoint, including the data type. All path parameters are required parameters.

For POST v3/actions/reach/get-actions/{requestUid}, {requestUid} is the path parameter.

Query parameters

Query parameters are used for sorting, filtering, selecting, and pagination of the API results. A query parameter is a key-value pair. The parameter value must be URL encoded. Multiple query parameters can be used by separating key-value pairs by an ampersand (&). Query parameters use the following format:

"paramName1={encodedParamValue1}&paramName2={encodedParamValue2}"

where paramNamen is the key for query parameter n and {encodedParamValuen} is the URL encoded value assigned to the query parameter n.

For nested parameters, use dot notation for paramNamen. The top level object is followed by a period (.), which is then followed by the parameter.

For the device status type in the GET /v3/reporting/devices resource, the top level object is deviceStatus and the parameter is type. The value for the paramNamen query parameter is:

deviceStatus.type

Request body schema parameters

The request body schema for each endpoint defines the required and optional parameters for each endpoint. These parameters are included in the payload and the payload is used to as part of the authentication for the request.

Empty payloads, such as those found in GET requests, should be set to an empty JSON object:

{}

Non-empty payloads need to be wrapped in a data tag:

The request body:

{
    "deviceUids": [
        "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-1aab032abcde",
        "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-2bbc032bcdef"
    ]
}

The request body is then wrapped with a data key:

{
    "data": {
        "deviceUids": [
            "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-1aab032abcde",
            "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-2bbc032bcdef"
        ]
    }
}
 ## Responses

The API call can have either a successful or failure response.

Successful response

The response body for a successful API call includes two sections, data and metadata.

The data section is the actual results returned from the resource. Each endpoint lists all of the possible parameters that may be returned in the data section. If a parameter has a null value, the parameter isn't returned in the response.

The metadata section includes the pagination string to get the next page of results. For more information, see the Pagination tab in Query parameters.

Failure response

Failed responses are made up of three sections, code, message, and details. The code and the message are the general reasons for the failure. If detailed error information is available, you can expand the details section to find an array of objects. Each object contains information on why the request was invalid, and if applicable, which field caused the error.

 # Authentication

All API requests must be authenticated. The Absolute API uses JSON Web Signature (JWS) cryptography to authenticate API requests. As part of the request, you need to generate an API token in the Secure Endpoint Console. Information from the token is used as part of JWS authentication.

API requests use either asymmetric or symmetric encryption.

Asymmetric encryption

Asymmetric encryption uses a key pair consisting of a public key and a private key. Only the public key is shared between parties. For this type of token, you generate a public and private key pair outside of the Secure Endpoint Console, and upload the public key to the Secure Endpoint Console. A token ID is created when you upload the public key, the token ID becomes part of the JOSE header. The private key is used for encryption and you are the only party that has access to the private key.

Symmetric encryption

Symmetric encryption uses a key that is shared between parties. For symmetric encryption, you generate a token ID with a secret key directly in the Secure Endpoint Console. The secret key is the shared key.

There are many libraries available for JWS authentication, such as the libraries listed by JWT.io. You can also work from Getting started: Create your request.

 ## JSON Web Signature construction

JSON Web Signature (JWS) consists of three parts concatenated with a period (.). Each part is base64url encoded.

BASE64URL(UTF8(JWS JOSE Header)) || '.' ||
BASE64URL(JWS Payload) || '.' ||
BASE64URL(JWS Signature)

JWS JOSE (JavaScript Object Signing and Encryption) Header: A JSON object containing the parameters used in the cryptographic operation

JWS Payload: A JSON object containing the payload for the API request

JWS Signature: A JSON object containing the signature generated from the JOSE Header and the JWS Payload using the algorithm specified in the JOSE Header

For in-depth information on JSON Web Signature (JWS), see RFC 7515.

Example values

The examples in this document use the following values to compute the JSON Web Signature:

These are examples only. The public and private keys are examples and cannot actually be used to generate a signature.

Example token ID
ce9778bf-exam-p1ec-afe3-91e9355603a3
Example secret key
a1bdcd23e45fHn6JNxU/CulSiR7feComPEMcQp8k9bKFDfLE6v+//ROJcbVLaZ1qsaZpygsecretKeyExample==
Example public key
-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
ABcdEfGHIoZIzj0CAQYIKoZIzj0DAQcDQgAEEVs/o5+uQbTjL3chynL4wXgUg2R9
q9UU8I5mEovUf86QZ7kOBIjJwqnzD1omagedT9POxgPublicKeyExample==
-----END PUBLIC KEY-----
Example private key
-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
ABcDEFGHICPJqF12Zd7Y2xUabq34odtrqTI3W7EWJwRTvF7ewETXoAoGCCqGSM
49AwEHoUQDQgAER5wRCKw7wCTjaQ7/FTmMRFhl3+Rg4a29qkrL0QsxOIc6Ae/n
WYU3CifATMvHBxcCQ+B8U6PrivateKeyExample==
-----END PRIVATE KEY-----

For checking your own JSON Web Signature, you can use the JWT debugger tool for the Header and the Payload.

Using the Verify Signature portion of the tool requires you to enter your credentials. Credentials are like passwords and should not be shared with anyone.

JWS JOSE Header

The JWS JOSE Header is an object that contains a number of key-value pairs, or header parameters. These parameters are used to describe the cryptography used. The content of the JWS JOSE Header is converted to UTF8 and then base64url encoded. This value becomes the input for the JWS Signature.

Header parameter Description Example
alg

The algorithm used for signing

  • ES256: Asymmetric Key Cryptography algorithm Elliptical Curve Digital Signature Algorithm using the P-256 elliptical curve algorithm and SHA-256 encryption algorithm

    Used for asymmetric encryption

  • HS256: Hash based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) with SHA-256 encryption

    Used for symmetric encryption

 "alg": "ES256"
kid

Key ID parameter

The token ID created in the Secure Endpoint Console

 "kid": "ce9778bf-exam-p1ec-afe3-91e9355603a3"
method

One of the following HTTPS request methods, in uppercase:

  • GET
  • PUT
  • POST
  • DELETE

 "method": "POST"
content-type The media type of the resource "content-type": "application/json"
uri The request path excluding the hostname and query parameters "uri": "/v3/actions/reach/get-actions"
query-string

The query parameters consisting of key-value pairs

Values are URL encoded

 "query-string": "orderBy=esn%2CdeviceName%3Adesc%2CdeviceUid%3Aasc"
issuedAt The UNIX Epoch date and time (UTC) in milliseconds when the request is created "issuedAt": 1638572152000

Asymmetric JOSE Header

The following is an example of the JOSE Header for POST /v3/actions/reach/get-actions. This example uses asymmetric encryption and the ES256 algorithm.

The query string filters the results to show actions created from 2022-01-01T00:00:00.000Z to 2022-02-01T00:00:00.000Z with an action status of Failed.

The values in the query-string key-value pairs are URL encoded:

Original query-string:

createdFromDateTime=2022-01-01T00:00:00.000Z&createdToDateTime=2022-02-01T00:00:00.000Z&actionStatus=Failed

URL encoded query-string:

createdFromDateTime=2022-01-01T00%3A00%3A00.000Z&createdToDateTime=2022-02-01T00%3A00%3A00.000Z&actionStatus=Failed

JWS JOSE Header content:

{
"alg": "ES256",
"kid": "ce9778bf-exam-p1ec-afe3-91e9355603a3",
"method": "POST",
"content-type": "application/json",
"uri": "/v3/actions/reach/get-actions",
"query-string": "createdFromDateTime=2022-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z&createdToDateTime=2022-02-01T00%3A00%3A00Z&actionStatus=Failed",
"issuedAt": 1638572152000
}

The result after converting to UTF8 and base64url encoding:



Symmetric JOSE Header

The following is an example of the JOSE Header for GET /v3/reporting/applications. This example uses symmetric encryption and the HS256 algorithm.

The query string sorts the results by ESN (Identifier) in ascending order, then by device name is descending order, and finally by device UID in ascending order.

The values in the query-string key-value pairs are URL encoded:

Original query-string:

orderBy=esn,deviceName:desc,deviceUid:asc

URL encoded query-string:

orderBy=esn%2CdeviceName%3Adesc%2CdeviceUid%3Aasc

JWS JOSE Header content:

{
"alg": "HS256",
"kid": "ce9778bf-exam-p1ec-afe3-91e9355603a3",
"method": "GET",
"content-type": "application/json",
"uri": "/v3/reporting/applications",
"query-string": "orderBy=esn%2CdeviceName%3Adesc%2CdeviceUid%3Aasc",
"issuedAt": 1638572152000
}

The result after converting to UTF8 and base64url encoding:



JWS Payload

The JWS Payload contains the API request payload. When the request payload is not empty, wrap the payload with a data key. For requests that use the GET method, set the payload to an empty json object. The content is base64url encoded. This value becomes input for the JWS Signature.

Non-empty JWS Payload

The following example contains parameters in the payload:

The original request body for POST /v3/actions/reach/get-actions is a JSON object containing an array of device UIDs.

The deviceUids in the payload are examples only.

{
    "deviceUids": [
        "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-1aab032abcde",
        "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-2bbc032bcdef"
    ]
}

The request body is then wrapped with a data key.

{
    "data": {
        "deviceUids": [
            "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-1aab032abcde",
            "56be8d1f-2eb8-4e9b-bbd6-2bbc032bcdef"
        ]
    }
}

JWS Signature

The signature is generated from the JOSE Header and the JWS Payload using the algorithm specified in the JOSE Header and the client private key. The JWS JOSE Header and the JWS Payload are concatenated with a period (.) and encoded using the algorithm specified in the JOSE Header. The result is base64url encoded.

Asymmetric JWS Signature

Asymmetric encryption uses the ES256 algorithm. For ES256, the client private key is the private key from the token you created.

The JWS signature input (line breaks are for display purposes only) for POST /v3/actions/reach/get-actions.

 ## API tokens

To create and authenticate an API request, you need to create an API token in the Secure Endpoint Console. When you create your API token in the console, you are provided with the token ID that is used as part of the request authentication.

For more information, see Creating API tokens in the online help.

By default, the token has the same permissions as your assigned user role. This means that if you have access to certain functionality in the Secure Endpoint Console, the token you create has equivalent access in the API. If your user account is assigned to a single device group when the token is created, the token is assigned that device group. If your user account's device group assignment changes in the future, the token isn't updated. The token is still assigned to the original device group.

API token permissions

When you create the token, you can modify the token's permissions. You can't assign permissions to a token that your user role doesn't have, but you can remove permissions. For added security, limit the API token to the minimum permissions required for its intended use. Once the token is created, the permissions for the token can't be changed.

If the user role associated with the token is assigned dual approval limits, devices in the request created using the API token are included in the device total. Requests created using the API that exceed the daily threshold also require approval.

If the user account associated with the token is suspended or deleted, the token is no longer valid. If the user is deleted, the API token is also deleted.

Permission requirements

To use an endpoint, the token generally requires the same feature permissions that your user role requires to perform the action in the console, with some differences. For specific information about the permission (or permissions) required to use each endpoint, refer to the Permissions section in the overview for each resource.

API token expiry

Tokens have an expiry date. The expiry date can be up to one year from the day the token is created. You can continue to use the token until 23:59:59 UTC on the day the token expires. Before a token expires, you can edit the expiry date in the Secure Endpoint Console. For more information, see API authentication in the online help.

Creating a token

You can create a token that uses either asymmetric or symmetric encryption.

Asymmetric encryption

To create a token that supports asymmetric encryption, you first must generate an ECDSA-SHA256 public and private key pair outside of the Secure Endpoint Console. Once the keys are generated, you upload the public key in the console. For more information on EDCSA, see RFC 6605.

To create your elliptical curve keys, you use the OpenSSL command-line tool. The public and private key pair are generated using the prime256v1 curve.

After you have created your elliptical curve keys, you upload the public key into the Secure Endpoint Console. Uploading the key creates your API token, and provides the token ID required for authentication.

The following files are created as a result of creating your elliptical curve keys:

The files are examples only. They cannot actually be used to generate a signature.

Example ec256-key-pair.pem

The elliptical curve parameters and private key:

It is imperative that you keep your EC private key secure. It is comparable to a password—do not share it with anyone.

-----BEGIN EC PARAMETERS-----
BggqhOPExample==
-----END EC PARAMETERS-----
-----BEGIN EC PRIVATE KEY-----
MHcCAQEEIM+oHeLG0rhP8lPYW4IWky0de8ayDgM+mCWfWmH/zCZEoAoGCCqGSM49
AwEHoUQDQgAEs1gtNZG++HYIi7hLiXpM74OIbkF+lTYPowrgRzVXT+uENXVGbBcb
wc0nsh0r86jK+84j+tECKeyPairExample==
-----END EC PRIVATE KEY-----
Example privateKey.pem

The EC256 private key in PKCS#8 PEM format:

It is imperative that you keep your private key secure. It is comparable to a password—do not share it with anyone.

-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
ABcDEFGHICPJqF12Zd7Y2xUabq34odtrqTI3W7EWJwRTvF7ewETXoAoGCCqGSM
49AwEHoUQDQgAER5wRCKw7wCTjaQ7/FTmMRFhl3+Rg4a29qkrL0QsxOIc6Ae/n
WYU3CifATMvHBxcCQ+B8U6PrivateKeyExample==
-----END PRIVATE KEY-----
Example publicKey.pem

The EC256 public key that you upload to the Secure Endpoint Console:

-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
ABcdEfGHIoZIzj0CAQYIKoZIzj0DAQcDQgAEEVs/o5+uQbTjL3chynL4wXgUg2R9
q9UU8I5mEovUf86QZ7kOBIjJwqnzD1omagedT9POxgPublicKeyExample==
-----END PUBLIC KEY-----

Symmetric encryption

To create a token that supports symmetric encryption, you create a token in the Secure Endpoint Console using the generate option. Generating the token provides the token ID and the secret key required for authentication.

 # Sorting

Sorting is done using the sortBy query parameter. If the endpoint supports sorting, the sortBy query parameter lists the fields that can be used. If the sortBy query parameter is not shown for the endpoint, the endpoint does not support sorting.

Some endpoints, like GET /v3/reporting/devices, only support sorting using one field. For these endpoints, the sortBy query parameter is defined as The sorting field and the direction of sorting.

Others, like GET /v3/reporting/applications, support sorting using multiple fields. When using multiple fields, the sortBy parameter accepts a comma-delimited list of fields. For these endpoints, the sortBy query parameter is defined as A comma-delimited list of sorting keys and the direction of sorting.

You can also specify the sort order direction as ascending or descending by adding :asc or :desc at the end of the field. If you do not include the sort order direction, the results are sorted in ascending order.

Sorting options are validated. If you include an invalid sorting option in your request, the request results in a 400 response.

The parameter value, which is the comma-delimited list of fields, must be URL encoded.

To sort the results of the GET /v3/reporting/applications endpoint by esn (Identifier) in ascending order, then by deviceName in descending order, and then by deviceUid in ascending order, use the following query parameter:

"sortBy=esn,deviceName:desc,deviceUid:asc"

URL encoded:

"sortBy=esn%2CdeviceName%3Adesc%2CdeviceUid%3Aasc"
 # Filtering

Filtering is done using query parameters. There are two types of filtering: simple filtering and advanced filtering.

 ## Simple filtering

Most of the endpoints support simple filtering. Simple filtering is done using the query parameters specified for each endpoint. In addition to the query parameters used for sorting, selecting, and pagination, the Query Parameters section of each endpoint lists the query parameters that you can use for filtering.

For example, you could filter the GET /v3/reporting/devices endpoint using the agentStatus query parameter. You can use multiple query parameters by separating each key-value pair with an ampersand (&).

The parameter values must be URL encoded.

To filter the results of the GET /v3/reporting/devices endpoint to include only Active devices for a specific user, use the username and the agentStatus query parameters.

"username=ABCCORP\tjordan&agentStatus=A"

URL encoded:

"username=ABCCORP%5Ctjordan&agentStatus=A"
 ## Advanced filtering

Advanced filtering is only available for the GET /v3/reporting/devices-advanced and GET /v3/reporting/applications-advanced endpoints.

More advanced Open Data Protocol (OData) style filtering is available on the GET /v3/reporting/devices-advanced resource in Device Reporting and the GET /v3/reporting/applications-advanced resource in Software Reporting using the filter query parameter. Advanced filtering allows you to use a combination of logical and comparison operators on a select number of fields, which are listed in the filter parameter for both endpoints. The fields listed can be combined using the eq (equals), and, and or logical operators, as well as () (parentheses) for precedence grouping. Strings must be surrounded in '' (single quotes).

The entire filter parameter value must be URL encoded.

To filter the results of the GET /v3/reporting/devices-advanced endpoint to find:

  • devices where the Absolute Identifier (ESN) starts with 1A2B (string)

    esnStartsWith eq '1A2B'

    URL encoded:

    esnStartsWith%20eq%20%271A2B%27

  • the platform OS type is Windows or Mac (string with precedence grouping)

    (platformOSType eq 'Windows' or platformOSType eq 'Mac')

    URL encoded:

    (platformOSType%20eq%20%27Windows%27%20or%20platformOSType%20eq%20%27Mac%27)

  • the device last checked in before January 1, 2022 (string <date-time>)

    lastConnectedDateTimeUtcTo eq '2022-01-01T00:00:00.000Z'

    URL encoded:

    lastConnectedDateTimeUtcTo%20eq%20%272022-01-01T00%3A00%3A00.000Z%27

  • the device has been reported Stolen (boolean)

    isStolen eq true

    URL encoded:

    isStolen%20eq%20true

Final filter query parameter:

filter=esnStartsWith eq '1A2B' and (platformOSType eq 'Windows' or platformOSType eq 'Mac') and lastConnectedDateTimeUtcTo eq '2022-01-01T00:00:00.000Z' and isStolen eq true

URL encoded:

filter=esnStartsWith%20eq%20%271A2B%27%20and%20(platformOSType%20eq%20%27Windows%27%20or%20platformOSType%20eq%20%27Mac%27)%20and%20lastConnectedDateTimeUtcTo%20eq%20%272022-01-01T00%3A00%3A00.000Z%27%20and%20isStolen%20eq%20true
 ## Finding parameters that can be used as filters

The query parameters and filter fields used to filter the results have a similar structure. Each one starts with the parameter name, and most of them end in a suffix that indicates the type of match. For example, to filter the results using agent status, the query parameter or filter field would start with agentStatus. To match a value, use the parameter name by itself, agentStatus. To include results that don't match a value, use the parameter name followed by Not, agentStatusNot. The possible suffixes are:

  • AnyOf
  • Contains
  • Empty
  • EndsWith
  • From
  • FromInclusive
  • Not
  • NotContains
  • NotEndsWith
  • NotStartsWith
  • StartsWith
  • To
  • ToInclusive

Not every parameter that is returned in the response can be used to filter the results. To determine if you can filter on a parameter, you need to search the list of query parameters when using simple filtering or the list of filter fields when using advanced filtering. If they apply to the endpoint, the sortBy, select, nextPage, and pageSize parameters are listed first in the Query Parameters section. For simple filtering, all other parameters that you can use to filter the results are listed in alphabetical order. For advanced filtering, the fields that can be used in the filter query parameter are listed in alphabetical order.

Most endpoints use simple filtering. To see if you can filter the results for a specific parameters, go to the Query Parameters section for the endpoint. If the query parameters are hidden, like in GET configurations/custom-data-collector/datapoints, expand the list.

For the GET /reporting/devices and GET /reporting/applications endpoints, there are a large number of parameters. The parameters for selecting, sorting, and pagination are grouped together. To view them, expand the group. The parameters used for filtering are also grouped together. Within the filtering group, the filtering parameters are also grouped by the fields available for filtering. These groups are listed in alphabetical order.

You want to filter the results of GET /reporting/devices based on deviceName. Once you expand the filtering parameters, you look for the group of parameters for deviceName. After you expand the deviceName group, you discover you can filter the results using any of the following:

  • deviceName
  • deviceNameEmpty
  • deviceNameNot
  • deviceNameNotStartsWith
  • deviceNameStartWith

For advanced filtering, which is only used in GET /reporting/devices-advanced and GET /reporting/applications-advanced, click show options in the filter query parameter description. You can then look through the list to see if you can filter on a specific parameter, and what types of matches are available.

 # Selecting

Selecting is done using the select query parameter. For each endpoint, the select parameter lists the fields that you can select in the API results. To select multiple fields, use a comma-delimited list of fields. The parameter value, which is the comma-delimited list of fields, must be URL encoded.

Although select supports nested parameters, the top level object and nested parameters cannot both be used in select at the same time.

To only return the esn (Identifier) and username from the GET /v3/reporting/devices endpoint, use the following query parameter:

"select=esn,username"

URL encoded:

"select=esn%2Cusername"

If the select query parameter is not shown for the endpoint, the endpoint does not support selecting.

Parameters that have a null value aren't returned in the response body. This means that a parameter may not be included in the response even though you specifically selected it.

 # Pagination

Pagination consists of two part: setting the page size and getting the next page of results.

Setting the page size

The pageSize query parameter is used to configure the number of results returned per page. This query parameter is only available for endpoints where the number of records returned is configurable. For endpoints that support pageSize, the description indicates the default number of records returned, and the maximum number of records that can be returned.

To return the first 20 records from the GET /v3/reporting/devices endpoint, use the following query parameter:

"pageSize=20"

The result is the same when it is URL encoded:

"pageSize=20"

Getting the next page of results

Each response contains a metadata section after the data section. Within the metadata section is the nextPage parameter. The value is used in the nextPage query parameter to get the next page of results. If it is not included as part of the request, the first page of results is returned.

Add the nextPage parameter to the existing query parameter. If you modify the query parameter in any way, the endpoint will not accurately return the next set of results.

The response body contains the nextPage parameter in the metadata section.

"metadata": {
"pagination": {
"nextPage": "AnExample2U3NWQ2MjNjMWNkZDQ0NmIyYTg2NTAwNTJjNDM5ZjFhMzA0OTZlNDVhNjg1OTAxZDBlZDljOTU2ODUxIiwiMjIwODNlZTctMjljOC00ZmIzLWI5ODItNTVjMWFiNDZjYWVlIl0="
}
}

Use this value in the nextPage query parameter in your next API request to get the next page of results. To return the the next 20 records from the GET /v3/reporting/devices endpoint, use the following query parameter:

"pageSize=20&nextPage=AnExample2U3NWQ2MjNjMWNkZDQ0NmIyYTg2NTAwNTJjNDM5ZjFhMzA0OTZlNDVhNjg1OTAxZDBlZDljOTU2ODUxIiwiMjIwODNlZTctMjljOC00ZmIzLWI5ODItNTVjMWFiNDZjYWVlIl0="

The result is the same when it is URL encoded:

"pageSize=20&nextPage=AnExample2U3NWQ2MjNjMWNkZDQ0NmIyYTg2NTAwNTJjNDM5ZjFhMzA0OTZlNDVhNjg1OTAxZDBlZDljOTU2ODUxIiwiMjIwODNlZTctMjljOC00ZmIzLWI5ODItNTVjMWFiNDZjYWVlIl0="
 # Getting started: Create your credentials

The Absolute API requires you to create an API token in the Secure Endpoint Console.

Asymmetric encryption

For asymmetric encryption, complete both of the following steps:

Step 1: Create your keys

Step 2: Create your API token

Symmetric encryption

For symmetric encryption, only complete Step 2: Create your API token.

 ## Create your keys

Asymmetric encryption requires you to create an EC256 public key and private key.

This step is for asymmetric encryption only. If you are using symmetric encryption, go to Step 2: Create your API token.

Step 1: Create your keys

Complete the following steps using the OpenSSL command-line tool.

To create your keys:

  1. Run the following command to generate an elliptical curve (EC256) private key:

    openssl ecparam -genkey -name prime256v1 -out ec256-key-pair.pem

  2. Run the following command to convert the EC256 private key into PKCS#8 PEM format:

    openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -inform pem -in ec256-key-pair.pem -outform pem -nocrypt -out privateKey.pem

  3. Run the following command to generate the EC256 public key:

    openssl ec -in ec256-key-pair.pem -pubout -out publicKey.pem

The following files are created in the OpenSSL /bin folder:

  • ec256-key-pair.pem
  • privateKey.pem
  • publicKey.pem
 ## Create your API token

Creating your API token is done in the Secure Endpoint Console.

Asymmetric encryption

For asymmetric encryption, upload your public key from Step 1: Create your keys.

Symmetric encryption

For symmetric encryption, generate a token.

Step 2: Create your API token

To create an API token:

  1. Log in to the Secure Endpoint Console as user with the Manage permission for API credentials.
  2. Click Create API token.
  3. In Add title, give the token a name.
  4. [Optional] To help identify the token, click the field under the title and enter a Description for this request.

  5. Do one of the following:

    • Asymmetric encryption:

      1. Click Upload public key (supports only v3).

      2. Enter the public key you generated in Step 1: Create your keys. The starting -----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY----- and ending -----END PUBLIC KEY----- lines are optional.

    • Symmetric encryption:
      • Select Generate Token.

  6. Click the Expiration date field and set an expiration date at least one day in the future by doing one of the following:

    • Enter a date in YYYY-MM-DD format

    • Use the Calendar picker to select a date

    • Select one of the predefined expiry date ranges

    If you do not set the Expiration, the expiration date defaults to 90 days.

  7. To change a token's permissions, select View, Manage, and Other Actions for each permission you want to add. Clear View, Manage, and Other Actions for each permission you want to remove. If you select Manage for a permission, View is automatically selected. If you don't change the permissions, the token has the same permissions as your assigned user role.

    Token permissions can't be modified once the token is created.

    To include all the permissions assigned to your user role, scroll ot the bottom of the Permissions section and click Select All. To remove all the permissions, click Clear.

    Assigned device group is for your information only.

  8. [Optional] Enter the IP addresses that you want to allow to access the API. Both IPv4 and IPv6 IP addresses in single and CIDR format are accepted. If no IP addresses are entered, the API can be accessed from any IP address. Approved IP addresses can be added to a token after it has been created.

    1. Enter or copy and paste one of the following in to Approved IP Address:

      • An individual IP address
      • A list of IP addresses separated by a space ( ), comma (,), semi-colon (;), or line break

    2. Click Add or press Enter.

      IP addresses are listed below the entry field. Validation is done on each IP address. If validation fails, you see Invalid IP address. Do one of the following:

      • To delete the IP address, click .
      • To edit the IP address, click in the IP address, make your changes, and press Tab or click away from the IP address. Validation is done on the updated IP address.

      Duplicate entries are ignored.

  9. Click Save.

    After you click Save, none of the fields can be edited. To make changes, you need to edit the token.

  10. From the Token Key Details section, do one of the following to capture the token information:

    • To copy the token information

      1. Click in the Token ID field or click Copy beside the token ID and paste the token ID to a text file.

      2. [Generated token only] Click in the Secret key field or click Copy beside the secret key and paste the secret key to the text file.

      3. Save the file to a secure location on your computer.

    • [Generated token only] To download the token ID and secret key, click Download Token. The token ID and secret key are downloaded in a .token file to your operating system's downloads folder. You can use a text editor, such as Notepad, to open the file.

      If you close this dialog without downloading or copying the secret key for generated tokens, you cannot retrieve it later. Record or save the secret key now, or you must delete this token and create a new one.

  11. After you have captured the token information, click Close.

On the API Token Management page, the new token is added to your list of tokens. An API token updated event is logged to Event History. For more information on token management, see the API Management section in the online help.

It is imperative that you keep your private keys and secret keys secure. They are comparable to passwords—do not share them with anyone.

 # Getting started: Create your request

Now that you have created your credentials, select a language to work in. In the selected language, update the script sample and one of the request examples.

Available script samples:

  • Postman
  • Python
  • PowerShell
  • Java
  • C#
  • Node.js
  • Bash
 ## Postman

After creating your API token, complete the following steps:

  • Step 1: Update the script sample
  • Step 2: Update the request example

Step 1: Update the script sample

To use Postman, you set both the Body and Pre-request Script sections. Update either the asymmetric or symmetric script sample.

Postman: Asymmetric script sample

To update the script sample:

  1. In Postman, set the request to POST.
  2. Enter the API access URL in Enter request URL:
    If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com, use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.

function callPublicApi(jsrasign, request) {
    eval(jsrasign);
    
    // Prepare timestamp in milliseconds (In UTC/ISO format)
    var issuedAt = Math.floor(Date.now() + 60*1000)
    // Set headers for JWT
    var header = {
        'alg': 'ES256',
        'kid' : request.kid,
        'method' : request.method,
        'content-type': request.contentType,
        'uri': request.uri,
        'query-string': request.queryString,
        'issuedAt' : issuedAt
    };
    
    // Wrap the payload in the "data" key
    var data = {
       'data': request.payload
    };
    
    var sHeader = JSON.stringify(header);
    var sPayload = JSON.stringify(data);
    
    var sJWT = KJUR.jws.JWS.sign(header.alg, sHeader, sPayload, privateKey);
    console.log('Signed and encoded JWT', sJWT)
    pm.environment.set('jwsReq',sJWT);
}

    • Fill in your secret key from Step 2: Create your API token in $SecretKey.
  2. If your response includes a file, such as a Reach script file (ZIP) or a Certificate of Sanitization (PDF), fill in the file path and file name (including the extension) where you want to save the file in $FilePath.
  3. Update the API access URL in $RequestUrl, if required for your login URL.
    If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com, use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com, use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.

  4. If your response includes a file, update the #### OUTPUT API RESULTS #### section to use the second block of code.
$Algorithm="HS256"
$ContentType="application/json"

# Fill in the token ID for your API token
$TokenId=""
# Fill in the secret key for your API token
$SecretKey=""
# If you are downloading a file, enter the destination path
$FilePath=""

# Code snippet from "Update the request example" defining the request goes here ...

    # Grab Unix Epoch Timestamp and add desired expiration.
    $issat = [long][double]::parse((Get-Date -Date $((Get-Date).addseconds($ValidforSeconds).ToUniversalTime()) -UFormat %s)) *1000

    [hashtable]$header = @{alg = $Algorithm; kid=$TokenId; method=$Method; 'content-type'=$ContentType; uri=$Uri; 'query-string'=$QueryString; issuedAt=$issat}

    $headerjson = $header | ConvertTo-Json -Compress
    $payloadjson = $Payload | ConvertTo-Json -Compress | %{[regex]::Unescape($_)}
    Write-Host "Header"
	Write-Host $headerjson
	Write-Host "Payload"
    Write-Host $payloadjson

    $headerjsonbase64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($headerjson)).Split('=')[0].Replace('+', '-').Replace('/', '_')
    $payloadjsonbase64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($payloadjson)).Split('=')[0].Replace('+', '-').Replace('/', '_')
	Write-Host "JWS Header"
    Write-Host $headerjsonbase64
	Write-Host "JWS Payload"
    Write-Host $payloadjsonbase64

    $ToBeSigned = $headerjsonbase64 + "." + $payloadjsonbase64

    $SigningAlgorithm = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.HMACSHA256

    $SigningAlgorithm.Key = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($SecretKey)
    $Signature = [Convert]::ToBase64String($SigningAlgorithm.ComputeHash([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($ToBeSigned))).Split('=')[0].Replace('+', '-').Replace('/', '_')
    Write-Host "JWS Signature"
	Write-Host $Signature
    $token = "$headerjsonbase64.$payloadjsonbase64.$Signature"
	Write-Host "Final JWS Web Signature"
    Write-Host $token

$apiMethod = "POST"
# Update $RequestUrl, if required:
# If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com,
# use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com,
# use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.eu2.absolute.com,
# use https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com, 
# use https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate.

$RequestUrl = "https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate"
$apiHeader = "content-type:text/plain"

function Failure {
$global:helpme = $body
$global:helpmoref = $moref
$global:result = $_.Exception.Response.GetResponseStream()
$global:reader = New-Object System.IO.StreamReader($global:result)
$global:responseBody = $global:reader.ReadToEnd();
Write-Host -BackgroundColor:Black -ForegroundColor:Red "Status: A system exception was caught."
Write-Host -BackgroundColor:Black -ForegroundColor:Red $global:responsebody
break
}

#### OUTPUT API RESULTS ####

# Example when your output doesn't include a file
try {$Result = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $RequestUrl -Method $apiMethod -Body $token -ErrorAction:Stop -UseBasicParsing
    $HTTPStatus = $Result.StatusCode
    Write-Host "API Response : HTTP = " $HTTPStatus
    Write-Host $Result
} catch {
    Failure
}

Java: Asymmetric script sample

To update the script sample:

  1. Enter your credentials.

    • Fill in your token ID from Step 2: Create your API token in String tokenID.
    • Fill in the file path for the private key from Step 1: Create your keys in String filePath.
  2. Update the API access URL in String requestUrl, if required for your login URL.
    If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com, use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com, use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.eu2.absolute.com, use https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com, use https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate.
import org.jose4j.jws.AlgorithmIdentifiers;
import org.jose4j.jws.JsonWebSignature;

import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.nio.file.Files;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

import java.security.KeyFactory;
import java.security.PrivateKey;
import java.security.Security;
import java.security.spec.PKCS8EncodedKeySpec;

import okhttp3.Call;
import okhttp3.MediaType;
import okhttp3.OkHttpClient;
import okhttp3.Request;
import okhttp3.RequestBody;
import okhttp3.Response;
import okhttp3.ResponseBody;

public class Test {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Used to get the "ECDSA" KeyFactory instance
        Security.addProvider(new org.bouncycastle.jce.provider.BouncyCastleProvider());
        // Fill in the token ID for your API token
        String tokenId = "";
        // Fill in the path to your privateKey.pem file
        String filePath = "";
        PrivateKey key = null;
        try {
            byte[] content = Files.readAllBytes(Paths.get(filePath));
            String pkcs8Pem = new String(content, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
            // Remove the "BEGIN" and "END" lines, as well as any whitespace
            pkcs8Pem = pkcs8Pem.replace("-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----", "");
            pkcs8Pem = pkcs8Pem.replace("-----END PRIVATE KEY-----", "");
            pkcs8Pem = pkcs8Pem.replaceAll("\\s+","");
            byte[] pkcs8EncodedBytes = org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64.decodeBase64(pkcs8Pem);
            KeyFactory factory = KeyFactory.getInstance("ECDSA");
            PKCS8EncodedKeySpec privKeySpec = new PKCS8EncodedKeySpec(pkcs8EncodedBytes);
            key = factory.generatePrivate(privKeySpec);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        // Update the requestUrl, if required:
        // If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com,
        // use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
        // If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com,
        // use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.
        // If you log in to https://cc.eu2.absolute.com,
        // use https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate.
		// If you log in to https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com, 
		// use https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate.

        String requestUrl = "https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate";
        OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient();

        /**** Code snippet from "Update the request example" defining the request goes here ... ****/

        JsonWebSignature jws = new JsonWebSignature();
        jws.setHeader("alg", "ES256");
        jws.setHeader("kid", tokenId);
        jws.setHeader("issuedAt", System.currentTimeMillis());
        // Set the signature algorithm on the JWS that will integrity protect the payload
        jws.setAlgorithmHeaderValue(AlgorithmIdentifiers.ECDSA_USING_P256_CURVE_AND_SHA256);

        // Set the signing key on the JWS
        jws.setKey(key);
        jws.setDoKeyValidation(false); // relaxes the key length requirement

        jws.setHeader("method", method);
        jws.setHeader("content-type", contentType);
        jws.setHeader("uri", uri);
        jws.setHeader("query-string", queryString);
        jws.setPayload(payload);

        try{
            String jwsCompactSerialization = jws.getCompactSerialization();
            // Post it with okhttpclient
            RequestBody body = RequestBody.create(jwsCompactSerialization, MediaType.parse("text/plain"));

            Request request = new Request.Builder()
                    .url(requestUrl)
                    .post(body)
                    .build();

            Call call = client.newCall(request);
            Response response = call.execute();
            ResponseBody responseBody = response.body();
            System.out.println(response.code());

Step 1: Update the script sample

Update either the symmetric script sample with your credentials and the API access URL.

Bash: Symmetric script sample

To update the script sample:

  1. Enter your credentials.

    • Fill in your token ID from Step 2: Create your API token in TOKEN_ID.
    • Fill in your secret key from Step 2: Create your API token in TOKEN_SECRET.
  2. Update the API access URL in REQUEST_URL, if required for your login URL.
    If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com, use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com, use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.eu2.absolute.com, use https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate.
    If you log in to https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com, use https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate.
#!/bin/bash
#set -x
# Fill in the token ID for your API token
TOKEN_ID=""
# Fill in the secret key for your API token
TOKEN_SECRET=""

# Update the REQUEST_URL, if required:
# If you log in to https://cc.absolute.com,
# use https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.us.absolute.com,
# use https://api.us.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.eu2.absolute.com,
# use https://api.eu2.absolute.com/jws/validate.
# If you log in to https://cc.fr1.absolutegov.com, 
# use https://api.fr1.absolutegov.com/jws/validate.

REQUEST_URL="https://api.absolute.com/jws/validate"


### Code snippet from "Update the request example" defining the REQUEST variables goes here ...


# Get current timestamp (issuedAt)
ISSUED_AT=$(($(date +%s) * 1000))  # Current timestamp in milliseconds
# Construct JWS header in JSON format
JWS_HEADER=$(jq -c -n \
  --arg alg "HS256" \
  --arg kid "$TOKEN_ID" \
  --arg issuedAt "$ISSUED_AT" \
  --arg method "$METHOD" \
  --arg contentType "$CONTENT_TYPE" \
  --arg uri "$URI" \
  --arg queryString "$QUERY_STRING" \
  '{
    alg: $alg,
    kid: $kid,
    issuedAt: $issuedAt,
    method: $method,
    "content-type": $contentType,
    uri: $uri,
    "query-string": $queryString
  }')
# Function to encode data in URL-safe Base64 (no padding)
base64url_encode() {
  echo -n "$1" | openssl base64 -e | tr -d '=' | tr '/+' '_-' | tr -d '\n'
}
# Encode header and payload
ENCODED_HEADER=$(base64url_encode "$JWS_HEADER")
ENCODED_PAYLOAD=$(base64url_encode "$PAYLOAD")
# Create the JWS signing input
SIGNING_INPUT="$ENCODED_HEADER.$ENCODED_PAYLOAD"
# Generate the signature using HMAC-SHA256
SIGNATURE=$(echo -n "$SIGNING_INPUT" | openssl dgst -sha256 -hmac "$TOKEN_SECRET" -binary | base64 | tr -d '=' | tr '/+' '_-' | tr -d '\n')
# Construct the final JWS token
JWS_TOKEN="$ENCODED_HEADER.$ENCODED_PAYLOAD.$SIGNATURE"
# Debugging: Print the JWS token (optional)
#echo "JWS Token: $JWS_TOKEN"
# Send the request using cURL (forcing raw text/plain body)
curl -X POST "$REQUEST_URL" \
  -H "Content-Type: text/plain" \
  --data "$JWS_TOKEN"
